tool.name: MethylIT: Evaluate DMPs classification
tool.command: Rscript '$__tool_directory__/methylit_evaluate_dimp_class.R' #if str($center_cond.center) == "yes": --center '$specify_center_cond.center' #end if --classifier '$classifier' --column '$column' --control_names '$control_names' --input '$input' #if str($classifier) in ["logistic", "pca_logistic"]: #if str($specify_interactions_cond.specify_interactions) == "yes": --interactions '$specify_interactions_cond.specify_interactions.interactions' #end if #end if --n_pc $n_pc --num_boot $num_boot --num_cores \${GALAXY_SLOTS:-4} --output_html '$output_html' --output_type '$output_type' --prop $prop #if str($specify_pval_column_cond.specify_pval_column) == "yes": --pval_column '$specify_pval_column_cond.pval_column' #end if #if str($scale_cond.scale) == "yes": --scale '$scale_cond.scale' #end if --script_dir '$__tool_directory__' --seed $seed --treatment_names '$treatment_names' #if str($output_log_cond.output_log) == "yes": &>'$output_log'; #else: &>output_log.txt; if [[ $? -ne 0 ]]; then cp output_log.txt '$output_data_frame'; cp output_log.txt '$output_grange'; fi #end if

param.name: input
param.label: File containing a pDMP object
param.help: Typically produced by the MethylIT: Select cytosine positions tool

param.name: control_names
param.label: Names of the control sample columns in the input GRange objects
param.help: Enter a comma-separated list if more than one item

param.name: treatment_names
param.label: Names of the treatment sample columns in the input GRange objects
param.help: Enter a comma-separated list if more than one item

param.name: column
param.label: Select column names to be used for the predictor variables

param.name: classifier
param.label: Select classification model
param.option: pca.lda (linear discriminant analysis with principal component analysis as predictor variables)
pca.logistic (logistic regression model using the principal component estimated with principal component analysis as predictor variables)
pca.qda (quadratic discriminant analysis using principle components as predictor variables)

param.name: specify_interactions
param.label: Specify interactions to consider in the logistics regression model?
param.help: --interactions: applied only if selected classification models include logistic or pca.logistic

param.name: specify_pval_column
param.label: Specify the column containing p-values from the Grange objects in the input?

param.name: pval_column
param.label: Index of the GRanges column containing the p-values

param.name: n_pc
param.label: Number of principal components to use if the classifier is not 'logistic'

param.name: scale
param.label: Scale variables to have unit variance before the analysis takes place?

param.name: prop
param.label: Proportion to split the dataset used in the logistic regression into two subsets, training and testing

param.name: num_boot
param.label: Number of bootstrap validations to perform in the evaluation of the logistic regression 'group versus divergence' at DMPs

param.name: seed
param.label: Seed value for random number generation

tool.help:
**What it does**
Return the evaluation of the classification of DMPs into two clases for a given cutpoint: DMPS from control and DMPs from treatment samples.
The regulatory methylation signal is also an output from a natural process that continuously takes place across the ontogenetic development of the organisms. So we expect to see methylation signal on natural ordinary conditions. To distinguish a control methylation signal from a treatment, three classification models are provided: 1) logistic, 2) Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) and 3) Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA). In particular, four predictor variables can be used: Hellinger divergence 'hdiv', total variation 'TV', probability of potential DMP 'wprob' and DMP genomic coordinated 'pos'. Principal component analysis (PCA) is used to convert a set of observations of possibly correlated predictor variables into a set of values of linearly uncorrelated variables (principal components, PCs). The PCs are used as new, uncorrelated predictor variables for LDA, QDA, and logistic classifiers.
A classification result with low accuracy and compromising values from other classification performance indicators suggest that the treatment does not induce a significant regulatory signal different from control.
